å…¶ä¸­ $\text{PRF}_n$ ä¸­çš„ $n$ æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªè‡ªç„¶æ•°ï¼Œä»£è¡¨å‡½æ•°çš„å‚æ•°ä¸ªæ•°ã€‚

$\text{rec} \ f \ g$ ï¼ˆå‡è®¾å‚æ•°åˆ—è¡¨ä¸º $(n, x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n)$ï¼‰å°±æ˜¯

é™¤äº†æ ‡å‡†çš„ LTL è¿ç®—ä¹‹å¤–ï¼Œå¸¦è¿‡å»ä¿¡æ¯çš„ LTL ï¼ˆpLTLï¼‰æ–°å¢äº†ä¸¤ä¸ªåŸºæœ¬è¿ç®—ç¬¦ $Y$ å’Œ $S$.

Since çš„å¼±åŒ–ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼Œ $a \widetilde S b$ è¡¨ç¤º è‡ªä» $b$ æ›¾ç» æˆç«‹è¿‡ä¹‹å $a$ ä¸€ç›´æˆç«‹ï¼Œæˆ–è€… $a$ è‡ªå¤ä»¥æ¥ä¸€ç›´æˆç«‹ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥ç†è§£ä¸ºâ€œå‡è®¾åœ¨å²å‰æ—¶ä»£ï¼Œ$b$ æˆç«‹è¿‡ä¸€ä¸‹â€çš„ $S$

    å¼±åŒ–å·²ç»å‰æå·²ç»è¢«æ»¡è¶³çš„å­å…¬å¼åŸå› æ˜¯ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä»ä¸Šé¢å¼±åŒ–ç‰ˆæœ¬çš„è¿ç®—ç¬¦çš„å®šä¹‰å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å°†è¿™äº›è¿ç®—ç¬¦çœ‹ä½œ å…¶å¯¹åº”çš„å¼ºåŒ–ç‰ˆæœ¬ çš„å‰ææ¡ä»¶åœ¨â€œä¹‹å‰â€è¢«æ»¡è¶³è¿‡çš„ç‰ˆæœ¬ã€‚ å¼ºåŒ–ä¹‹å‰æ²¡æœ‰æ»¡è¶³çš„å­å…¬å¼çš„åŸå› æ˜¯ï¼Œå¦‚æœè¿™ä¸ªå­å…¬å¼æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå¼±åŒ–ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼Œä¸”ä¹‹å‰å®ƒçš„å‰ææ¡ä»¶æ²¡æœ‰è¢«æ»¡è¶³ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå½“å‰å®ƒå’Œå®ƒçš„å¼ºåŒ–ç‰ˆæœ¬æ˜¯ç­‰æ•ˆçš„ã€‚

function factorial(n) {

entry.content:
æœ¬æ–‡å‡è®¾è¯»è€…çŸ¥é“ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯ Hoare Logicã€‚

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆ Hoare Logic ä¸å¤Ÿ

å‡è®¾æˆ‘ä»¬æœ‰äº†ä¸‹é¢ä¸¤æ®µç¨‹åºï¼š

while n != 0 {

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å†™å‡ºä¸¤è€…çš„ pre å’Œ post condition:

// r = 1 && n >= 0 && n = n0
while n != 0 {
    r *= n;

}
// r = n0!

// z = z0
z += z;
// z = 2 * z0

ç„¶è€Œï¼Œå¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬æŠŠä¸¤æ®µç¨‹åºåˆå¹¶èµ·æ¥ï¼Œæ•´ä½“çš„ pre å’Œ post condition å¹¶éæ˜¯ä¸¤è€…çš„ç®€å•åˆå¹¶ï¼š

// r = 1 && n >= 0 && n = n0 **&& z = z0**

    r *= n;

// r = n0! **&& z = z0**

// z = z0 **&& z = z0**

// z = 2 * z0 **&&r = n0!**

å¯è§ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¿…é¡»å°†ä¸€äº›å’Œå±€éƒ¨å˜é‡æ— å…³çš„æ–­è¨€åŠ å…¥ pre å’Œ post conditionï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´ï¼Œä»»ä½•å±€éƒ¨å˜é‡çš„ pre å’Œ post condition éƒ½å½±å“æ•´ä½“ã€‚

ä¸ºäº†åŒºåˆ†ç¨‹åºä¸­çš„å±€éƒ¨å’Œæ•´ä½“ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°† Hoare Logic ä¸­çš„ pre å’Œ post condition ä¸­çš„ conjunctionï¼ˆ$\wedge$ï¼‰æ”¹ä¸º separating conjunction ï¼ˆ$*$ï¼‰ã€‚

Ï‰-è¯­è¨€

Let $Î£$ be a set of symbols (not necessarily finite). Following the standard definition from formal language theory, $Î£*$ is the set of all finite words over $Î£$. Every finite word has a length, which is a natural number. Given a word w of length n, w can be viewed as a function from the set $\{0,1,...,nâˆ’1\} â†’ Î£$, with the value at i giving the symbol at position i. The infinite words, or Ï‰-words, can likewise be viewed as functions from $\mathbb{N}$ to $Î£$. The set of all infinite words over $Î£$ is denoted $Î£^{\omega}$. The set of all finite and infinite words over $Î£$ is sometimes written $Î£^{\infty}$ or $Î£^{\leq \omega}$. â€”â€” Wikipedia

BÃ¼chi è‡ªåŠ¨æœº2

A deterministic BÃ¼chi automaton is a tuple A = (Q,Î£,Î´,q0,F) that consists of the following components:
Q is a finite set. The elements of Q are called the states of A.
Î£ is a finite set called the alphabet of A.
Î´: Q Ã— Î£ â†’ Q is a function, called the transition function of A.
q0 is an element of Q, called the initial state of A.
FâŠ†Q is the acceptance condition. A accepts exactly those runs in which at least one of the infinitely often occurring states is in F.
In a (non-deterministic) BÃ¼chi automaton, the transition function Î´ is replaced with a transition relation Î” that returns a set of states, and the single initial state q0 is replaced by a set I of initial states.
â€”â€” Wikipedia

In Agda, æ‰€æœ‰èƒ½è¢« type checker è‡ªåŠ¨ â€œè½¬æ¢â€ çš„ä¸œè¥¿ä¹‹é—´éƒ½æ˜¯ judgemental equal çš„ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ä½ å¯ä»¥åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªè¦æ±‚æ”¾å…¥å‡½æ•° $f$ çš„åœ°æ–¹æ”¾å…¥ $\lambda x . f(x)$ï¼Œç±»å‹æ£€æŸ¥å™¨ä¸ä¼š complainï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬ judgemental equalã€‚

$$ \text{Eq-N} : N â†’ N â†’ Set $$ $$ \begin{align} \text{Eq-N}&(&0 &,& 0 &)& & := âŠ¤ \\ \text{Eq-N}&(&0 &,& suc(n) &)& & := âŠ¥ \\ \text{Eq-N}&(&suc(n) &,& 0 &)& & := âŠ¥ \\ \text{Eq-N}&(&suc(m) &,& suc(n)&)& & := \text{Eq-N}(m, n) \end{align} $$

$$ \text{Eq-N-refl}: (n : N) â†’ \text{Eq-N}(n, n) $$ $$ \begin{align} \text{Eq-N-refl} &(&zero &)& & := tt \\ \text{Eq-N-refl} &(&suc(n)&)& & := \text{Eq-N-refl}(n) \end{align} $$ $$ \text{identity-to-Eq-N} : (x : N) â†’ (y : N) â†’ x â‰¡ y â†’ \text{Eq-N}(x,y) $$ $$ \begin{align} \text{identity-to-Eq-N}(x,x,refl_x) & := \text{Eq-N-refl}(x) & \end{align} $$ $$ \text{Eq-N-to-identity} : (x : N) â†’ (y : N) â†’ \text{Eq-N}(x,y) â†’ x â‰¡ y $$ $$ \begin{align} \text{Eq-N-to-identity} &(&0 &,& 0&,& eqnxy) & := refl \\ \text{Eq-N-to-identity} &(&suc(x)&,& suc(y)&,& eqnxy) & := cong(suc,\text{Eq-N-to-identity}(x,y,eqnxy)) \end{align} $$

Homotopy

$$ ind_{htpy} : (\Pi_{(g: \Pi_{(x:A)}B(x))}\Pi_{(H: f \sim g)}P(g,H)) â†’ P(f, \text{refl-htpy}_f) $$

$$ ind_{htpy}(s, f, \text{refl-htpy}_f) := s(f, \text{refl-htpy}_f) $$

fiber

$$ fib_f(b) := \Sigma_{(a : A)} f(a) = b $$

å¯¹åº”äº† b åœ¨ f ä¸Šçš„åŸåƒã€‚

pointed type

Basically a type with a point.

The type of a pointed type is: $$ \mathcal{U}_* := Î£_{(A : \mathcal{U})} A $$

An example of a pointed type is $(â„• , 0)$. Pointed maps are maps between pointed types that preserve the point.

$$ (A â†’* B) := Î£{(f : A â†’ B)} f(a) = b $$

loop space

$$ \begin{align} \Omega & : \mathcal{U}_* â†’ \mathcal{U}_{*} \\ \Omega(A, a) & := (a = a, \text{refl}) \end{align} $$

We can apply $\Omega$ multiple times to get iterated loop spaces:

$$ \begin{align} \Omega^0(A, a) & := (A, a) \\ \Omega^1(A, a) & := \Omega(A, a) \\ \Omega^2(A, a) & := \Omega(\Omega(A, a)) \\ â‹¯ \\ \Omega^{n+1}(A) & := \Omega(\Omega^n(A, a)) \end{align} $$

ç±»å‹/å‡½æ•°çš„å±æ€§

is-empty

$$ \text{is-empty}(A) := A â†’ \bot $$

sec/retr

å‡è®¾ $f : A â†’ B$ï¼Œsec è¡¨ç¤ºå‡½æ•°å­˜åœ¨å³é€†ã€‚

$$ \text{sec}(f) := \Pi_{(g:Bâ†’A)} f âˆ˜ g \sim id $$

retr è¡¨ç¤ºå‡½æ•°å­˜åœ¨å·¦é€†ã€‚

$$ \text{retr}(f) := \Pi_{(h:Bâ†’A)} h âˆ˜ f \sim id $$

retr ä¹‹æ‰€ä»¥ç§°ä¸º retrï¼Œæ˜¯å› ä¸º $h$ å¯èƒ½åªæ˜¯å°† B çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå­é›†(å³ $f$ çš„åƒ)æ˜ å°„åˆ°äº† A ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶æˆ‘ä»¬å°±è¯´ A æ˜¯ B çš„ä¸€ä¸ªæ”¶ç¼©ï¼ˆretractionï¼‰ã€‚

is-equiv

$$ \text{is-equiv}(f) := sec(f) \times retr(f) $$

$$ \text{is-equiv}(f) := \Sigma_{(g : B â†’ A)} (f \circ g = id_B) \times (g \circ f = id_A) $$

é‡è¦çš„ç­‰ä»·å…³ç³»

  • For an equivalence relation $R$: $$ ([x]_R = [y]_R) â‰ƒ R(x, y) $$
  • symmetry of equality $$ (x = y) â‰ƒ (y = x) $$
  • concat on path $p: x = y$ $$ ğ‘â‹…- : (ğ‘¦ = ğ‘§) â‰ƒ (ğ‘¥ = ğ‘§) $$ $$ -â‹…q : (ğ‘¥ = ğ‘¦) â‰ƒ (ğ‘¥ = ğ‘§) $$
  • transport on path $p: x = y$ $$ tr_ğµ(ğ‘) : ğµ(ğ‘¥) â‰ƒ ğµ(ğ‘¦) $$
  • any section and any retraction of an equivalence is again an equivalence.
  • equivalent types have equivalent identity types ($e : A â‰ƒ B$, then $ap_e$ is an equivalence function)
  • "axiom" of choice $$ \begin{align} choice &: & \Pi_{(x:A)}\Sigma_{(ğ‘¦:ğµ(ğ‘¥))}ğ¶(ğ‘¥, ğ‘¦) â‰ƒ \Sigma_{(ğ‘“:\Pi_{(ğ‘¥:ğ´)} ğµ(ğ‘¥))}\Pi_{(ğ‘¥:ğ´)}ğ¶(ğ‘¥, ğ‘“(ğ‘¥)) \\ choice(h) &:= & (ğœ†ğ‘¥. pr_1(h(ğ‘¥)), ğœ†ğ‘¥. pr_2 (h(ğ‘¥))) \end{align} $$
  • $sec(pr_1) â‰ƒ \Pi_{(ğ‘¥:ğ´)} ğµ(ğ‘¥)$

is-contr

$$ \text{is-contr}(A) := \Sigma_{(c : A)} \Pi_{(x : A)} c = x $$

$$ \text{is-contr}(f) := \Pi_{(b : B)} \text{is-contr}(fib_f(b)) $$

We call $f$ a contractible map.

$$ \text{is-contr}(f) â†” \text{is-equiv}(f) $$

Important contractible types

  • $âŠ¤$
  • $âŠ¥$
  • $Î£_{(x:A)} a = x$
  • Product of contractible types is contractible
  • Observational equal on $â„•$, $Bool$ and coproduct type, ie. $\text{Eq-N}(n,m)$. with one of n and m fixed by $\Sigma$, ie. $\Sigma_{(n:N)} \text{Eq-N}(m,n)$
  • A type $A$ is contractible if and only if the identity map on $A$ is constant.
  • A map is an equivalence if and only if its fibers are contractible

is-coh-invertible

å¯¹äºä¸€ä¸ªå‡½æ•° $f : A \rightarrow B$, å¦‚æœä»–æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ª equivalence, å…¶é€†ä¸º $g$, $g$ ä¸ºå³é€†çš„è¯æ®ä¸º homotopy $G$, $g$ ä¸ºå·¦é€†çš„è¯æ®ä¸º homotopy $H$ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶å­˜åœ¨ Homotopy $K : G \cdot f \sim f \cdot H$ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç§° $f$ ä¸º coherently invertible mapã€‚

$$ \text{is-coh-invertible}(f) := \Sigma_{(g : B â†’ A)} \Sigma_{(G : f \circ g \sim id_B)} \Sigma_{(H : g \circ f \sim id_A)} \Sigma_{(K : G \cdot f \sim f \cdot H)} (g, G, H, K) $$

Any coherently invertible map is a contractible map.

is-emb

$$ \text{is-emb}(f) := (x, y : A) â†’ \text{is-equiv}(cong\ f\ {x}\ {y}) $$

is-prop

$$ \text{is-prop}(A) := \Pi_{(x,y : A)} \text{is-contr}(x = y) $$

Identity types on A are contractable.

or

$$ \text{is-prop}(A) := \Pi_{(x,y : A)} x = y $$

Any two terms on A are equal.

$$ \text{is-prop}(A) := A \rightarrow \text{is-contr}(A) $$

A is not empty and contractable (can be contracted to the given point).

Important props

  • Everything is contractible type is a prop.
  • If $A$ is a prop, $A â‰ƒ B$, then $B$ is a prop. And vice versa, all props are equivalent to each other.s
  • Observational equal on $â„•$ and Bool, ie. $\text{Eq-N}(n, m)$. Since it is equivalent to identity type on these types, identity type on these types is also a prop.
  • A product of props is a prop.
  • Given a prop A and $\text{is-subtype}(B)$ of A, then $\text{is-prop}(Î£_{(x:A)} B(x))$
  • $\text{is-emb}$, $\text{is-surj}$ and $\text{is-equiv}$.
  • $\text{is-contr}(A)$, $\text{is-prop}(A)$ itself, $\text{is-set}(A)$, ..., $\text{is-trunk}_k(A)$ is a prop.
  • Given a prop B, $A â†’ B$ is a prop, a special case is, the negation of a type ($\neg A$) is a prop.
  • $\text{is-unital}(G)$, $\text{is-group}(G)$, for any semigroup $G$.
  • A map $f : A â†’ B$ is an embedding if and only if its fibers are propositions.
  • A type ğ´ is a proposition if and only if the identity map on ğ´ is weakly constant ($\Pi_{(x,y:A)} f (x) = f (y)$).

is-subtype

$$ \text{is-subtype}(B) := (x : A) â†’ \text{is-prop} (B(x)) $$

We say $B$ is a subtype of $A$.

is-set

$$ \text{is-set}(A) := \Pi_{(x,y : A)} \text{is-prop}(x = y) $$

is-trunc-k

$$ \begin{align} \text{is-trunc}_{-2}(A) & := \text{is-contr}(A) \\ \text{is-trunc}_{k+1}(A) & := \Pi_{(x,y:A)}\text{is-trunc}_k(x = y) \end{align} $$

a map $f : A â†’ B$ is k-truncated if its fibers are k-truncated.

  • Product ($\Pi$) of k-truncated types is k-truncated.
  • retract of k-truncated type is k-truncated
  • $f: Aâ†’B$, B is ğ‘˜-type, then "A is k-type" â†” "f is k-type"
  • If $ğ‘“ : ğ´ â†’ ğµ$ is an embedding, and ğµ is a (ğ‘˜ + 1)-type, then so is ğ´.
  • ğ‘“ is (ğ‘˜ + 1)-truncated, then $ap_f$ is k-truncated, and vice versa.
  • ğµ(ğ‘¥) is ğ‘˜-truncated for each $ğ‘¥ : ğ´$ â†” $Î£(ğ‘¥:ğ´) ğµ(ğ‘¥)$ is ğ‘˜-truncated

is-small

$$ \text{is-small}_{\mathcal{U}}(A) := Î£_{(X:\mathcal{U})} A â‰ƒ X $$

for a map $f : A â†’ B$, $f$ is small if all its fibers are small.

is-locally-small

$$ \text{is-locally-small}_{\mathcal{U}}(A) := \Pi_{(x, y : A)} \text{is-small}(x = y) $$

for a map $f : A â†’ B$, $f$ is locally small if all its fibers are locally small.

All small types are locally small in the same universe.

Any proposition is locally small in any universe.

Any univalent universe U is locally U-small.

is-equivalence-class

For $R$ to be an equivalence relation, a subtype $P : A â†’ Prop$

$$ \text{is-equivalence-class}(P) := âˆƒ(x:A)âˆ€(y:A) P(y) â†” R(x, y) $$

is-effective

For $R$ to be an equivalence relation,

$$ \text{is-effective}(f) := (x, y : A) â†’ (f(x) â‰¡ f(y) â‰ƒ R(x, y)) $$

entry.title: é‡æ–°å¼€å§‹å­¦æ•°å­¦ â€¢ è´å¶æ–¯å› æœæ¨ç†ï¼ˆ4ï¼‰
entry.content:
Overfitting å’Œ Underfitting çš„æ¦‚å¿µå¤§å®¶éƒ½å¾ˆç†Ÿæ‚‰ï¼Œå°±ä¸èµ˜è¿°äº†ã€‚

è¯„ä¼°æ¨¡å‹å¥½å

Cross Validation

test the modelâ€™s predictive accuracy on a small part of the sample.

PSIS(Pareto-smoothed cross-validation)

lppd(log-pointwise-predictive-density)

ä¿¡æ¯é‡å‡†åˆ™ï¼ˆinformation criteriaï¼‰

likelihood-based measures of model fit that include a penalty for complexity.

AICã€WAIC ç­‰éƒ½æ˜¯ä¿¡æ¯é‡å‡†åˆ™çš„ä¾‹å­ã€‚

é˜²æ­¢ Overfitting çš„æ‰‹æ®µ

regularizing prior

ç®€å•æ¥è¯´å°±æ˜¯é€‰æ‹©æ›´â€œç´§â€çš„ priorã€‚

Multilevel model

æœ‰æ—¶æ•°æ®ä¸­å¯ä»¥æ˜¾ç°å‡ºä¸€äº›æ˜æ˜¾çš„åˆ†ç»„ï¼ˆclusterï¼‰ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ Multilevel model å¯ä»¥æ›´å¥½åœ°å¤„ç†è¿™ç§æƒ…å†µï¼Œé˜²æ­¢ç”±äºé‡å¤é‡‡æ ·ã€ä¸å‡è¡¡é‡‡æ ·å¯¼è‡´çš„ underfit æˆ– overfit é—®é¢˜ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶èƒ½æ›´å¥½çš„æ•æ‰ç»„é—´ã€ç»„å†…çš„å·®å¼‚ã€‚

ä¾‹å­

æ¯”å¦‚å…³äºèŒèšªæ­»äº¡ç‡çš„æ¨¡å‹ï¼š

$$ \begin{align} S_i &\sim Binomial(N_i, p_i) \\ logit(p_i) &= \alpha_{Tank[i]} \\ \alpha_{i} &\sim Normal(0, 1.5) \\ \end{align} $$

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å°†è¿™ä¸ªæ¨¡å‹â€œå‡çº§â€ä¸º Multilevel modelï¼š

$$ \begin{align} S_i &\sim Binomial(N_i, p_i) \\ logit(p_i) &= \alpha_{Tank[i]} \\ \alpha_{i} &\sim Normal(\overline \alpha, \sigma) \\ \overline \alpha &\sim Normal(0, 1.5) \\ \sigma &\sim Exp(1) \end{align} $$

ç›¸æ¯”äºé’ˆå¯¹æ¯ä¸ª Tank ä¼°è®¡ä¸€ä¸ªå®Œå…¨æ— å…³ $\alpha$ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªæ–°æ¨¡å‹é™åˆ¶äº† $\alpha$ çš„åˆ†å¸ƒï¼Œä½¿å¾— $\alpha$ ä¹‹é—´çš„å·®å¼‚æ›´å°ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ä¹Ÿæ›´å¥½åœ°æ•æ‰äº† $\alpha$ çš„åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

shrinkage

Multilevel model çš„ä¸€ä¸ªé‡è¦ç‰¹æ€§æ˜¯ shrinkageã€‚

å¯¹äºæ¯ä¸ªç»„ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éƒ½ä¼šä¼°è®¡ä¸€ä¸ª $\alpha$ï¼Œè¿™äº› $\alpha$ éƒ½éµå¾ªä»¥ $\overline \alpha$ ä¸ºå‡å€¼çš„æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

å¦‚æœæŸä¸ªç»„çš„æ•°æ®å¾ˆå°‘ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¿™ä¸ªç»„çš„æ•°æ®å¯¹ $\alpha$ çš„ä¼°è®¡ç›¸å¯¹ä¸æ˜¯å¾ˆå¯é ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªç»„çš„ $\alpha$ ä¼šæ›´æ¥è¿‘åˆ©ç”¨ $\overline \alpha$ è®¡ç®—å‡ºçš„å€¼ã€‚

å¦‚æœæŸä¸ªç»„çš„æ•°æ®å¾ˆå¤šï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¿™ä¸ªç»„çš„æ•°æ®å¯¹ $\alpha$ çš„ä¼°è®¡ç›¸å¯¹å¯é ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªç»„çš„ $\alpha$ ä¼šæ›´æ¥è¿‘åˆ©ç”¨è¿™ä¸ªç»„çš„æ•°æ®è®¡ç®—å‡ºçš„å€¼ã€‚

ä½†æ— è®ºå¦‚ä½•ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰ä½¿ç”¨å« $\overline \alpha$ çš„ multilevel æ¨¡å‹åšå‡ºçš„ä¼°è®¡éƒ½ä¼šæ¯”åŸæ¨¡å‹æ›´æ¥è¿‘ç›´æ¥ $\overline \alpha$ ä»£æ›¿ $\alpha$ çš„ä¼°è®¡ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªæ•ˆåº”ç§°ä¸º shrinkageã€‚

Pooling

  • Complete pooling. This means we assume that the population of clusters is invariant, the same as estimating a common intercept for all clusters.
  • No pooling. This means we assume that each cluster tells us nothing about any other cluster.
  • Partial pooling. This means using an adaptive regularizing prior.

ä¸€èˆ¬æ¥è¯´ä½¿ç”¨ Multilevel model å°±æ˜¯é‡‡ç”¨äº† partial poolingã€‚

Varying effects

varying intercepts: For each cluster in the data, we use a unique intercept parameter. eg. liveness of tadpoles in different tanks

varying slope: For each cluster in the data, we use a unique slope parameter. eg. busy/unbusy cafÃ© -> waitime

entry.title: é‡æ–°å¼€å§‹å­¦æ•°å­¦ â€¢ è´å¶æ–¯å› æœæ¨ç†ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰
entry.content:
è´å¶æ–¯æ¨¡å‹

è¦å»ºç«‹ä¸€ä¸ªè´å¶æ–¯æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ç¡®å®šæ¨¡å‹çš„è¾“å‡ºï¼ˆoutcomeï¼‰ç¬¦åˆä»€ä¹ˆåˆ†å¸ƒï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦é€‰æ‹©ä¸€ä¸ªä¼¼ç„¶å‡½æ•°ã€‚

eg.

$$ height \sim Normal(\mu, \sigma) $$

å¦‚ä½•é€‰æ‹©ä¼¼ç„¶å‡½æ•°

é€‰æ‹©ä¼¼ç„¶å‡½æ•°çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œè¦è€ƒè™‘ï¼š

  • æ•°æ®æœ¬èº«çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚æ˜¯æ•´æ•°è¿˜æ˜¯æµ®ç‚¹æ•°ï¼Œæ˜¯å¦æœ‰ä¸Šä¸‹ç•Œç­‰ï¼ˆEpistemological, which means philosophy behind knowledgeï¼‰ã€‚
  • è¦æè¿°çš„å¯¹è±¡åœ¨ç°å®ä¸­æ˜¯å¦‚ä½•åˆ†å¸ƒçš„ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚å¤§é‡éšæœºå½±å“ä¸‹ï¼Œæ•°æ®å¸¸å¸¸ï¼ˆå¤©ç„¶åœ°ï¼‰å‘ˆæ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒï¼ˆOntological, which means the nature of the worldï¼‰ã€‚

æ‰€é€‰æ‹©çš„ä¼¼ç„¶å‡½æ•°å¸¸å¸¸ä¼šéœ€è¦ä¼ å…¥å‚æ•°(parameters)ï¼Œå¯¹äºæ¯ä¸ªå‚æ•°ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦åœ¨ä¸€å¼€å§‹ä¼°è®¡å®ƒçš„åˆ†å¸ƒï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªåˆ†å¸ƒç§°ä¸ºè¿™ä¸ªå‚æ•°çš„å…ˆéªŒ(prior)ã€‚

eg.

$$ \sigma \sim Exp(?) $$

æœ‰äº›å‚æ•°å¯èƒ½å’Œä½ æ‰€çŸ¥é“çš„å…¶ä»–è¾“å…¥æœ‰å…³ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶ï¼Œè¿™äº›è¾“å…¥ç§°ä¸ºè‡ªå˜é‡ï¼ˆpredictor variableï¼‰ã€‚

eg.

$$ \mu = \alpha + \beta \times (weight - 150) $$

è¿™é‡Œçš„ $\alpha$ å’Œ $\beta$ æ˜¯æ–°å¢åŠ çš„å‚æ•°ï¼Œè€Œ $weight$ å°±æ˜¯è‡ªå˜é‡ã€‚

æ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘ä»¬æ•´ä¸ªçš„æ¨¡å‹å°±æ˜¯ï¼š

$$ \displaylines { height & \sim & Normal(\mu, \sigma) \\ \mu & = & \alpha + \beta \times weight \\ \alpha & \sim & Normal(?, ?) \\ \beta & \sim & Normal(?, ?) \\ \sigma & \sim & Exp(?) } $$

ç°åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ç¡®å®šæ¨¡å‹ä¸­è¿™äº› $?$ çš„å€¼ï¼Œå¹¶éªŒè¯è¿™äº›å€¼æ˜¯ç›¸å¯¹å¥½çš„ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªè¿‡ç¨‹ç§°ä¸º prior predictive checkã€‚

Prior predictive check

Prior predictive check çš„ç›®çš„æ˜¯æ£€æŸ¥æ¨¡å‹ä¸­çš„å…ˆéªŒåˆ†å¸ƒæ˜¯å¦åˆç†ã€‚

ä¸€èˆ¬æ¥è¯´ prior predictive check çš„æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯é€‰å®šä¸€ç»„ priorï¼Œç„¶åç”¨è¿™ç»„ prior ç”Ÿæˆä¸€äº›æ•°æ®ï¼Œçœ‹è¿™äº›æ•°æ®æ˜¯å¦åˆç†ã€‚

æ¯”å¦‚ä»¥ä¸Šé¢çš„ä¾‹å­æ¥è¯´ï¼Œå¦‚æœå–ä»¥ä¸‹çš„ priorï¼š

$$ \displaylines { height & \sim & Normal(\mu, \sigma) \\ \mu & = & \alpha + \beta \times (weight - 150) \\ \alpha & \sim & Normal(0, 1) \\ \beta & \sim & Normal(0, 1) \\ \sigma & \sim & Exp(1) } $$

é‚£ä¹ˆæ¨¡å‹å¯ä»¥ç”Ÿæˆï¼ˆå¤§é‡çš„ï¼‰è´Ÿæ•°çš„ heightï¼Œè¿™æ˜¾ç„¶æ˜¯ä¸åˆç†çš„ã€‚

æ ¹æ®ç»éªŒï¼Œäººçš„èº«é«˜å¤§çº¦åœ¨ 165 å˜ç±³å·¦å³ï¼Œä¸”èº«é«˜å’Œä½“é‡å‘ˆæ­£ç›¸å…³ï¼Œå› æ­¤ä¸€ç»„æ›´å¥½çš„ prior å¯ä»¥æ˜¯ï¼š

$$ \displaylines { height & \sim & Normal(\mu, \sigma) \\ \mu & = & \alpha + \beta \times (weight - 60) \\ \alpha & \sim & Normal(165, 20) \\ \beta & \sim & Normal(0.5, 0.2) \\ \sigma & \sim & Exp(1) } $$

å½“ç„¶ä½ ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥æœé›†æ›´å¤šçš„çŸ¥è¯†é€‰æ‹©æ›´å¥½çš„ priorï¼Œæˆ–è€…æ¢ç”¨æ›´åˆç†çš„åˆ†å¸ƒå‡½æ•°ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚è®© $\beta \sim \text{log-Normal}(?, ?)$ã€‚

å¦‚ä½•å­¦ä¹ å‚æ•°çš„å€¼

ä¸€ä¸ªå¸¸ç”¨çš„æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨ MCMCï¼ˆMarkov chain Monte Carloï¼‰ã€‚

ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯¹äºä»¥ä¸‹æ¨¡å‹ï¼š

$$ \displaylines { W & \sim & Binomial(9, p) \\ p & \sim & Normal(0.5, 0.1) } $$

å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ MCMC æ–¹æ³•æ¥å­¦ä¹  $p$ çš„å€¼ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ rethinking åŒ…å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

ulam(
    alist(
        W ~ dbinom(W + L, p), # binomial likelihood
        p ~ dnorm(0.5, 0.1) # uniform prior
    ),
    data = list(W = 6, L = 3)
)

åŠŸèƒ½ä¸Šç›¸å½“äºï¼š

W <- 6
L <- 3
# MCMC çš„ä¸€ä¸ª chain
n_samples <- 1000
p <- rep(NA, n_samples)
# prior
p[1] <- rnorm(1, 0.5, 0.1)
for (i in 2:n_samples) {
    # é€‰å–ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„ p
    p_new <- rnorm(1, p[i - 1], 0.1)
    # æ¯”è¾ƒæ–°æ—§ p çš„ç»“æœ
    q0 <- dbinom(W, W + L, p[i - 1])
    q1 <- dbinom(W, W + L, p_new)
    # åˆ¤æ–­æ˜¯å¦æ¥å—æ–°çš„ p
    p[i] <- ifelse(runif(1) < q1 / q0, p_new, p[i - 1])
}

entry.title: é‡æ–°å¼€å§‹å­¦æ•°å­¦ â€¢ è´å¶æ–¯å› æœæ¨ç†ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰
entry.content:
å› æœå…³ç³»å›¾ï¼ˆCausal graph, Causal DAGï¼‰

causal graphs (also known as path diagrams, causal Bayesian networks or DAGs) are probabilistic graphical models used to encode assumptions about the data-generating process.

The causal graph can be drawn in the following way. Each variable in the model has a corresponding vertex or node and an arrow is drawn from a variable X to a variable Y whenever Y is judged to respond to changes in X when all other variables are being held constant. Variables connected to Y through direct arrows are called parents of Y, or "direct causes of Y," and are denoted by Pa(Y).

ç®€å•æ¥è¯´å°±æ˜¯ç”¨æ¥æè¿°å› æœå…³ç³»çš„æœ‰å‘æ— ç¯å›¾ã€‚

æ··æ‚ï¼ˆconfoundingï¼‰

Letâ€™s define confounding as any context in which the association between an outcome Y and a predictor of interest X is not the same as it would be, if we had experimentally determined the values of X.

Let X be some independent variable, and Y some dependent variable. To estimate the effect of X on Y, the statistician must suppress the effects of extraneous variables that influence both X and Y. We say that X and Y are confounded by some other variable Z whenever Z causally influences both X and Y.

Multicollinearity means very strong correlation between two or more predictor variables.

In statistics, multicollinearity (also collinearity) is a phenomenon in which one predictor variable in a multiple regression model can be perfectly predicted from the others.

when the posterior distribution is very steep in some region of parameter space. Steep changes in probability are hard for a discrete physics simulation to follow. When that happens, the algorithm notices by comparing the energy at the start to the energy at the end.

One variable may depend upon another. For example, plants benefit from both light and water. But in the absence of either, the other is no benefit at all.

æ¯å•ä½æ—¶é—´å‘ç”ŸæŸäº‹ä»¶ $\lambda$ æ¬¡ï¼Œåˆ™ $Exp(Î»)$ ä»£è¡¨æ¯æ¬¡å‘ç”Ÿçš„æ—¶é—´é—´éš”çš„æ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

æ³Šæ¾åˆ†å¸ƒ / Poisson distribution

$$ Poisson(Î») $$

éšæœºäº‹ä»¶å‘ç”Ÿæ¬¡æ•°çš„æ•°å­¦æœŸæœ›å€¼å’Œæ–¹å·®å‡ä¸º $\lambda$ï¼Œåˆ™ $Poisson(Î»)$ ä¸ºå•ä½æ—¶é—´å†…éšæœºäº‹ä»¶å‘ç”Ÿçš„æ¬¡æ•°çš„æ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

æœä»æ³Šæ¾åˆ†å¸ƒçš„éšæœºå˜é‡ï¼Œå…¶æ•°å­¦æœŸæœ›ä¸æ–¹å·®ç›¸ç­‰ï¼Œå‡ä¸º $\lambda$ã€‚

å–æ ·æ ·æœ¬æ•°å¾ˆå¤§æ—¶å°†è¿‘ä¼¼æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

ä¼½ç›åˆ†å¸ƒ / Gamma distribution

$$ Gamma(a, \lambda) $$

å‘ç”Ÿ a æ¬¡ç‹¬ç«‹çš„éšæœºäº‹ä»¶ï¼Œæ¯å•ä½æ—¶é—´å‘ç”ŸæŸäº‹ä»¶ $\lambda$ æ¬¡ï¼Œåˆ™ $Gamma(a, \lambda)$ ä»£è¡¨è¿™ a æ¬¡äº‹ä»¶å‘ç”Ÿæ€»å…±æ‰€ç”¨æ—¶é—´çš„åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

a ä¸º 1 æ—¶ï¼Œé€€åŒ–ä¸ºæŒ‡æ•°åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

å‡ ä½•åˆ†å¸ƒ / Geometric distribution

$$ G(p) $$

å³ä¸åœåšå®éªŒç›´åˆ°æˆåŠŸä¸ºæ­¢ï¼Œåšå®éªŒçš„æ¬¡æ•°çš„æ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

è´ŸäºŒé¡¹åˆ†å¸ƒ / Negative binomial distribution

$$ NB(r, p) $$

å³ä¸åœåšå®éªŒç›´åˆ°ç¬¬ r æ¬¡æˆåŠŸä¸ºæ­¢ï¼Œåšå®éªŒçš„æ¬¡æ•°çš„æ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

r ä¸º 1 æ—¶ï¼Œé€€åŒ–ä¸ºå‡ ä½•åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

è´ŸäºŒé¡¹åˆ†å¸ƒå¯ä»¥çœ‹ä½œæ˜¯ Gamma åˆ†å¸ƒå’Œ Poisson åˆ†å¸ƒçš„ç»„åˆã€‚

$$ GammaPoisson(\lambda, \Phi) $$

å…¶ä¸­ï¼š

$$ r = \frac \lambda \Phi $$

$$ p = \frac 1 {1 + \Phi} $$

æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒ / Normal distribution

$$ N(\mu, \sigma^2) $$

å‡è®¾ä¸€ä¸ªå®éªŒå¯èƒ½æœ‰å‡ ç§ç­‰å¯èƒ½çš„ä¸åŒçš„ç»“æœï¼Œä»¥å¤šä¸ªï¼ˆè¶Šå¤šè¶Šå¥½ï¼‰è¿™æ ·çš„å®éªŒä¸ºä¸€ç»„ï¼Œå¤§é‡åšè¿™æ ·çš„å®éªŒï¼Œæ¯ç»„å®éªŒçš„ç»“æœä¹‹å’Œæœä»æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

$\beta$-binomial åˆ†å¸ƒ

$$ BetaBinomial(N, a, b) $$

æ˜¯ Beta å’Œ Binomial ç»„åˆçš„ç»“æœï¼Œå½“ $p$ æœä» $Beta(a, b)$ æ—¶ï¼Œ$Binomial(N, p)$ çš„åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

å³æ¯æ¬¡è¯•éªŒå¾—åˆ°â€œæˆåŠŸâ€ç»“æœçš„æ¦‚ç‡ç¬¦åˆ $Beta(a, b)$ï¼Œåš $N$ æ¬¡è¯•éªŒï¼Œå¾—åˆ°â€œæˆåŠŸâ€æ¬¡æ•°çš„æ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚

Bayesâ€™ theorem

$$ åéªŒæ¦‚ç‡ = normalize(ä¼¼ç„¶å‡½æ•° \times å…ˆéªŒæ¦‚ç‡) $$

æˆ–è€…ç”¨ç¬¦å·å†™ï¼š

$$ Pr(p|W) = \frac {Pr(W|p)Pr(p)} {Pr(W)} $$

è´å¶æ–¯æ•°æ®åˆ†æçš„æ­¥éª¤

1

æœ¬æ–‡ä¸¥æ ¼åŒºåˆ†äº‹ä»¶ï¼ˆå†™ä½œ $E_{å¤§å†™è‹±æ–‡å­—æ¯}$ï¼‰å’Œå˜é‡ï¼ˆç”¨æ™®é€šå¤§å†™è‹±æ–‡å­—æ¯è¡¨ç¤ºï¼‰ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ $E_A$ å¯èƒ½ä»£è¡¨äº‹ä»¶ $X=1$ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶å¯ä»¥ç»™ä»–åˆ†é…å˜é‡ $A$ï¼Œå› æ­¤ $Pr(E_A) \equiv Pr\{X=1\} \equiv Pr(A)$ã€‚

2

$,$ çš„ä¼˜å…ˆçº§é«˜äº $|$ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ $Pr(p|W,L)$ æ˜¯ $Pr(p|(W,L))$ã€‚

3

$Y \mathrel{\rlap{\perp}\mkern1mu\perp} X | Z$ çš„æ„ä¹‰æ˜¯ï¼šé™¤å» $Z$ çš„å½±å“åï¼ˆæ˜¾ç¤ºå‡ºï¼‰ $Y$ ä¸ $X$ æ— å…³ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ª conditional independency çš„ä¾‹å­ã€‚

entry.title: é‡æ–°å¼€å§‹å­¦æ•°å­¦ â€¢ æ•°ç†é€»è¾‘ï¼ˆ5ï¼‰
entry.content:
æˆ‘ä»¬çš„ç›®æ ‡æ˜¯å†™å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªå‡½æ•°ï¼Œè¾“å…¥ä¸€ä¸ª CTL æ¨¡å‹å’Œä¸€ä¸ª Formulaï¼Œè¾“å‡ºæ¨¡å‹ä¸­æ‰€æœ‰èƒ½ satisfy è¿™ä¸ª Formula çš„çŠ¶æ€é›†åˆã€‚

fn satisfiable_states(self: &CTLModule, formula: CTLFormula)

æ ¹æ® CTL ä¸­è¿æ¥è¯çš„å®šä¹‰ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å†™å‡ºï¼š

fn satisfiable_states(self: &CTLModule, formula: CTLFormula) {
    match formula {
        âŠ¤ => self.S,
        âŠ¥ => âˆ…,
        Atomic(atomic) => {s âˆˆ self.S | atomic is true in state s},
        Not(inner_formula) => self.S - model.sat(inner_formula),
        inner_formula1 âˆ§ inner_formula2 => model.sat(inner_formula1) âˆ© model.sat(inner_formula2),
        inner_formula1 âˆ¨ inner_formula2 => model.sat(inner_formula1) âˆª model.sat(inner_formula2),
        inner_formula1 â†’ inner_formula2 => model.sat(Not(inner_formula1) âˆ¨ inner_formula2),
        // suppose we want to solve EX instead of AX, following ones are similar
        AX(inner_formula) => model.sat(Not(EX(Not(inner_formula)))),
        A[inner_formula1 U inner_formula2] => sat(Not(E[Not(inner_formula2) U (Not(inner_formula1) âˆ§ Not(inner_formula2))] âˆ¨ EG Not(inner_formula2)))
        EF(inner_formula1) => sat(E[âŠ¤ U inner_formula1])
        EG(inner_formula1) => sat(Not(AF(Not(inner_formula1))))
        AG(inner_formula1) => sat(Not(EF(Not(inner_formula1))))

        EX(inner_formula) => todo!(),
        AF(inner_formula) => todo!(),
        E[inner_formula1 U inner_formula2] => todo!(),
    }
}

Now we've done the trivial cases and "merged" the other cases into three.

ç„¶åæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸€ä¸ªä¸ªè§£è¿™ä¸‰ä¸ª caseã€‚

EX

èƒ½æ»¡è¶³ EX(inner_formula) çš„çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯â€œå­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªåç»§çŠ¶æ€æ»¡è¶³ inner_formulaâ€ çš„çŠ¶æ€ã€‚

åªéœ€è¦å…ˆæ‰¾å‡ºæ‰€æœ‰èƒ½æ»¡è¶³ inner_formula çš„çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œå†æ‰¾å‡ºä»–ä»¬æ‰€æœ‰çš„å‰é©±çŠ¶æ€å³å¯ã€‚

EX(inner_formula) => {
    let direct_satisfy = model.sat(inner_formula);
    direct_satisfy
        .map(|satisfying_state| model.predecessors(satisfying_state))
        .union_all()
},

AF

èƒ½æ»¡è¶³ AF(inner_formula) çš„çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯â€œå¯¹äºæ‰€æœ‰ä»è¿™ä¸ªç‚¹åˆ†æ•£å‡ºå»çš„ branchï¼Œinner_formula éƒ½ä¼šåœ¨æŸçŠ¶æ€ä¸‹æˆç«‹â€çš„çŠ¶æ€ã€‚

é¦–å…ˆèƒ½æ»¡è¶³ inner_formula çš„æ‰€æœ‰ state è‚¯å®šæ»¡è¶³ä¸Šè¿°æ¡ä»¶ï¼Œç„¶åå¦‚æœæŸä¸ª state çš„å‰é©±çš„æ‰€æœ‰åç»§ä¹Ÿéƒ½æ»¡è¶³æ¡ä»¶ï¼Œé‚£â€œè¿™ä¸ª state çš„å‰é©±â€ä¹Ÿæ»¡è¶³æ¡ä»¶ã€‚

AF(inner_formula) => {
    let direct_satisfy = model.sat(inner_formula);
    let mut current_satisfied = direct_satisfy;
    let mut last_iteration_satisfied = None;
    while last_iteration_satisfied != current_satisfied {
        last_iteration_satisfied = Some(current_satisfied);
        current_satisfied = current_satisfied.union({s âˆˆ self.S | forall model.successor(s), s is in current_satisfied});
    }
    current_satisfied
}

EU

è¿™ä¸ª case ç¨å¾®å¤æ‚äº›ï¼ŒE[inner_formula1 U inner_formula2] çš„è¯­æ„æ˜¯å­˜åœ¨æŸä¸ª pathï¼Œä½¿å¾— inner_formula1 è‡³å°‘æˆç«‹åˆ° inner_formula2 æˆç«‹ä¸ºæ­¢ã€‚

é¦–å…ˆç”±äº U å¯¹ inner_formula2 æˆç«‹å inner_formula1 æ˜¯å¦ç»§ç»­æˆç«‹ä¸åšè¦æ±‚ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æ‰€æœ‰ inner_formula2 æˆç«‹çš„ state éƒ½æ»¡è¶³æ¡ä»¶ã€‚

æ¥ç€ï¼Œå¯¹äºæ‰€æœ‰å·²çŸ¥æ»¡è¶³æ¡ä»¶çš„çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œå¦‚æœä»–çš„å‰é©±èƒ½æ»¡è¶³ inner_formula1ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè¿™ä¸ªçŠ¶æ€ä¹Ÿæ»¡è¶³æ¡ä»¶ã€‚

E[inner_formula1 U inner_formula2] => {
    let satisfy_formula1 = model.sat(inner_formula1);
    let satisfy_formula2 = model.sat(inner_formula2);
    let mut current_satisfied = satisfy_formula2;
    let mut last_iteration_satisfied = None;
    while last_iteration_satisfied != current_satisfied {
        last_iteration_satisfied = Some(current_satisfied);
        current_satisfied = current_satisfied.union(model.successor(s).intersect(satisfy_formula1));
    }
}

å¦‚æ­¤ä¸€æ¥æˆ‘ä»¬å°±å®Œæˆäº†è¿™æ•´ä¸ªç®—æ³•ã€‚

entry.title: é‡æ–°å¼€å§‹å­¦æ•°å­¦ â€¢ æ•°ç†é€»è¾‘ï¼ˆ4ï¼‰
entry.content:
æ—¶åºé€»è¾‘

åœ¨é€»è¾‘ä¸­ï¼Œæœ¯è¯­æ—¶é—´é€»è¾‘è¢«ç”¨æ¥æè¿°ä¸ºè¡¨ç°å’Œæ¨ç†å…³äºæ—¶é—´é™å®šçš„å‘½é¢˜çš„è§„åˆ™å’Œç¬¦å·åŒ–çš„ä»»ä½•ç³»ç»Ÿã€‚ â€”â€” Wikipedia

åŸºäºæ¨¡å‹çš„ç¨‹åºæ­£ç¡®æ€§éªŒè¯ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ç°åœ¨å¸¸ç”¨çš„ TLA+ï¼ŒèƒŒåçš„åŸç†å°±æ˜¯æ—¶åºé€»è¾‘ã€‚

çº¿æ€§æ—¶é—´æ—¶åºé€»è¾‘ï¼ˆLTL, Linear-time Temporal Logicï¼‰

In logic, linear temporal logic or linear-time temporal logic(LTL) is a modal temporal logic with modalities referring to time. â€”â€” Wikipedia

Linear-time temporal logic, or LTL for short, is a temporal logic, with connectives that allow us to refer to the future. â€”â€” Logic in Computer Science

ç®€å•æ¥è¯´å°±æ˜¯æä¾›äº†æè¿°æ—¶é—´çš„å·¥å…·çš„æ—¶é—´é€»è¾‘ç³»ç»Ÿã€‚

è¿™ç§é€»è¾‘ç³»ç»Ÿå°†æ—¶é—´å»ºæ¨¡ä¸ºä¸€ç³»åˆ—ï¼ˆä¸åˆ†æ”¯çš„ï¼‰æ— é™å‘æœªæ¥å»¶ä¼¸çš„çŠ¶æ€ã€‚

å½¢å¼åŒ–è¡¨è¿°

$$\displaylines { Formula ::= \\ \top | \bot | p | \neg Formula | Formula \wedge Formula | Formula \vee Formula | Formula \rightarrow Formula \\ | X\ Formula | F\ Formula | G\ Formula | Formula\ U\ Formula | Formula\ W\ Formula | Formula\ R\ Formula } $$

å…¶ä¸­ $p$ æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªåŸå­å‘½é¢˜ã€‚

è¯­æ„

é™¤äº†å–œé—»ä¹è§çš„ $\wedge$ã€$\vee$ ç­‰ï¼Œæ—¶åºé€»è¾‘è¿˜æ·»åŠ äº†ä¸€äº›åˆ«çš„ï¼Œç”¨æ¥æè¿°çŠ¶æ€ä¹‹é—´å…³ç³»çš„è°“è¯ç¬¦å·1ï¼š

  • $X$ ä»£è¡¨ neXt stateï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ $X\ p$ å°±æ˜¯ $p$ åœ¨ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªçŠ¶æ€æˆç«‹ã€‚
  • $F$ ä»£è¡¨ some Future stateï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ $F\ p$ å°±æ˜¯ $p$ ä¸€å®šåœ¨æŸä¸ªæœªæ¥2çŠ¶æ€æˆç«‹ï¼Œå¸¸å†™ä½œ $\diamond$ã€‚
  • $G$ ä»£è¡¨ all future states (Globally)ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ $G\ p$ å°±æ˜¯ $p$ åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰æœªæ¥çŠ¶æ€æˆç«‹ï¼Œå¸¸å†™ä½œ $\square$ã€‚
  • $U$ ä»£è¡¨ Untilï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ $p\ U\ q$ å°±æ˜¯ $p$ ä¸€ç›´æˆç«‹ï¼Œâ€œç›´åˆ°â€3æœ‰ä¸€å¤© $q$ æˆç«‹ï¼Œè€Œä¸”ä¹Ÿ imply äº† $q$ çœŸçš„æ€»æœ‰ä¸€å¤©ä¼šæˆç«‹ã€‚
  • $W$ ä»£è¡¨ Weak untilï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ $p\ W\ q$ å°±æ˜¯ $p$ ä¸€ç›´æˆç«‹ï¼Œç›´åˆ°æœ‰ä¸€å¤© $q$ æˆç«‹ï¼Œä½†å¹¶ä¸ imply $q$ çœŸçš„æ€»æœ‰ä¸€å¤©ä¼šæˆç«‹ã€‚
  • $R$ ä»£è¡¨ Releaseï¼Œ$p\ R\ q$ ç­‰ä»·äº $\neg (\neg p\ U \neg q)$ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´ï¼Œ$p$ çš„æˆç«‹ é‡Šæ”¾äº† $q$ï¼Œä½¿å¾— $q$ å¯ä»¥ä¸å†æˆç«‹ã€‚

åˆ†æ”¯æ—¶åºé€»è¾‘ï¼ˆCTLï¼ŒComputation Tree Logicï¼‰

Computation tree logic (CTL) is a branching-time logic, meaning that its model of time is a tree-like structure in which the future is not determined; there are different paths in the future, any one of which might be an actual path that is realized. â€”â€” Wikipedia & Logic in Computer Science

ç®€å•æ¥è¯´å°±æ˜¯å¯ä»¥æè¿°æ•´ä¸ªæ‰§è¡Œæ ‘çš„é€»è¾‘ç³»ç»Ÿã€‚

ç›¸æ¯” LTLï¼ŒCTL å¤šå‡ºäº†â€œåˆ†æ”¯â€ï¼Œä½¿å¾—åŸæœ¬åœ¨ LTL é‡Œæ— æ³•è¡¨è¾¾çš„ â€œå­˜åœ¨â€ å¯ä»¥è¡¨è¾¾äº†ã€‚

å½¢å¼åŒ–è¡¨è¿°

$$\displaylines { Formula ::= \\ \top | \bot | p | \neg Formula | Formula \wedge Formula | Formula \vee Formula | Formula \rightarrow Formula \\ | AX\ Formula | EX\ Formula | AF\ Formula | EF\ Formula | AG\ Formula | EG\ Formula | A[Formula\ U\ Formula] | E[Formula\ U\ Formula] } $$

å…¶ä¸­ $p$ æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªåŸå­å‘½é¢˜ã€‚

CTL ä¸€èˆ¬ä¸åŒ…å« $W$ å’Œ $R$ã€‚

éœ€è¦æ³¨æ„çš„æ˜¯ï¼ŒCTL ä¸åŒ…æ‹¬â€œè¿ç”¨â€ LTL æ–°å¼•å…¥çš„è¿æ¥è¯ çš„å¥å­ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ LTL $FG\ p$ æ˜¯åˆæ³•çš„ LTLï¼Œä½† $A(FG\ p)$ å´ä¸æ˜¯åˆæ³•çš„ CTLã€‚

è¯­æ„

A æ˜¯ along All pathsï¼ˆä½†æˆ‘æ›´å€¾å‘äºç»§ç»­ä½¿ç”¨ Alwaysï¼‰, å³åé¢çš„ LTL åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰è·¯å¾„ä¸Šæˆç«‹ã€‚ E æ˜¯ there Exists one pathï¼Œå³åé¢çš„ LTL-like çš„å…¬å¼åœ¨æŸæ¡è·¯å¾„ä¸Šæˆç«‹ã€‚

CTL* å¯ä»¥çœ‹ä½œæ˜¯ LTL å’Œ CTL â€œå–é•¿è¡¥çŸ­â€ å¾—åˆ°çš„ç»“æœï¼Œå®ƒä¹Ÿæ˜¯ LTL å’Œ CTL çš„è¶…é›†ã€‚

åœ¨ CTL* ä¸­ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è‡ªç”±åœ°ä½¿ç”¨ $A$/$E$ å’Œ $X$/$F$/$G$/$U$ æ¥è¿ç»“å‘½é¢˜ã€‚

1

3

entry.title: å®šç†è¯æ˜å™¨èƒŒåçš„æ•°å­¦åŸç†
entry.content:
How it looks like

ç›¸æ¯”ä¸€ä¸Šæ¥å°±æ°æ‰¯å¤æ‚çš„æ•°å­¦ç†è®ºï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸å¦‚å…ˆæ¥çœ‹çœ‹ä¸€ä¸ªä½¿ç”¨å®šç†è¯æ˜å™¨ Lean 1 ç¼–å†™æ•°å­¦å®šç†çš„è¯æ˜çš„å®é™…ä¾‹å­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°±é€‰æ‹©æ¯”è¾ƒå®¹æ˜“è¯æ˜çš„å¾·æ‘©æ ¹å®šå¾‹æ¥è¯ï¼š

open Classical

theorem deMorgan : Â¬(p âˆ§ q) â†” Â¬p âˆ¨ Â¬q :=
  Iff.intro
    (Î» (left: Â¬(p âˆ§ q)) => (
      Or.elim (em p) 
        (Î» (hp: p) => Or.intro_right (Â¬p) (
          Î» (hq: q) => absurd âŸ¨ hp, hq âŸ© left
        ))
        (Î» (hnp: Â¬p) => Or.intro_left (Â¬q) hnp)
    ))
    (Î» (left: Â¬p âˆ¨ Â¬q) => (
      Or.elim left
        (Î» (hnp: Â¬p) (inner: p âˆ§ q) => absurd inner.left hnp)
        (Î» (hnq: Â¬q) (inner: p âˆ§ q) => absurd inner.right hnq)
    ))

çœ‹èµ·æ¥è¿™ä¸ªè¯æ˜å¥½åƒæ˜¯ç”±ä¸€äº› Î»ï¼ˆå°±åƒ Python ä¸­çš„ lambdaï¼Œin case ä½ æ²¡å­¦è¿‡â€œæ­£è§„â€çš„ FP è¯­è¨€ï¼‰å’Œä¸€äº›é«˜é˜¶å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆæ¯”å¦‚ Or.elimï¼‰ç»„æˆçš„ã€‚

é‚£è¿™äº›ä¸œè¥¿å‡­ä»€ä¹ˆèƒ½è¯æ˜è¿™ä¸ªå‘½é¢˜å‘¢ã€‚

è¿™å°±è¦ç‰µæ‰¯åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªå« Curry-Howard åŒæ„çš„ä¸œè¥¿äº†ã€‚

Curry-Howard åŒæ„

  1. å°†NFAçš„å¼€å§‹çŠ¶æ€åŠå…¶æ‰€æœ‰å¯é€šè¿‡$\epsilon$è¾¹çš„çŠ¶æ€æ˜ å°„ä¸ºDFAâ€‹çš„å¼€å§‹çŠ¶æ€
  2. å¦‚æœDFAä¸­çš„æ¯ä¸ªçŠ¶æ€éƒ½è¢«â€œè€ƒè™‘è¿‡â€ï¼Œåˆ™ç®—æ³•å®Œæˆ
  3. å¦åˆ™ï¼Œè€ƒè™‘DFAä¸­çš„ä¸€ä¸ªæ²¡æœ‰è¢«è€ƒè™‘è¿‡çš„çŠ¶æ€$N$ï¼š
    1. å¯¹å­—æ¯è¡¨é‡Œçš„æ¯ä¸ªå­—æ¯$ch$
    2. æ‰¾å‡ºè¿™ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹å¯¹åº”NFAä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰èŠ‚ç‚¹ç»è¿‡$ch$åŠ ä¸Šä»»æ„å¤šçš„$\epsilon$è¾¹èƒ½åˆ°è¾¾çš„æ‰€æœ‰çŠ¶æ€çš„é›†åˆ
      1. è‹¥è¿™ä¸ªé›†åˆæ˜¯DFAä¸­å·²ç»å­˜åœ¨çš„æŸä¸ªçŠ¶æ€$M$å¯¹åº”çš„NFAçŠ¶æ€é›†åˆçš„å­é›†ï¼Œåˆ™æ·»åŠ è¿çº¿$N + ch = M$
      2. å¦åˆ™å‘DFAä¸­æ·»åŠ æ–°çŠ¶æ€$P$ï¼Œå…¶å¯¹åº”NFAçŠ¶æ€é›†åˆå°±æ˜¯ä¸Šè¿°é›†åˆï¼Œå¦‚æœè¿™ä¸ªé›†åˆä¸­åŒ…å«æ¥å—çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè¿™ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹ä¹Ÿæ˜¯æ¥å—çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œå¹¶æ·»åŠ è¿çº¿$N+ch=P$
  4. æœ€ç»ˆå¾—åˆ°çš„DFAå³ä¸ºæ‰€æ±‚

ä»£ç 

ä»£ç è§Githubä»“åº“ã€‚

fun toDFA(): Deterministic {
        start as Nondeterministic.State
    // è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰è¢«è€ƒè™‘è¿‡çš„çŠ¶æ€, equivalentStates: ç»è¿‡ğœ€è¾¹èƒ½åˆ°è¾¾çš„çŠ¶æ€
    // ç”±äºDFAçŠ¶æ€æ²¡æœ‰å®Œå…¨è¢«æ„é€ å‡ºæ¥ï¼Œæ•…å­˜èµ·æ¥æ¯”è¾ƒå›°éš¾
    // æ‰€ä»¥å­˜å’Œè¿™ä¸ªDFAçŠ¶æ€å¯¹åº”çš„NFAçŠ¶æ€é›†
    val statesToFind = mutableSetOf(start.equivalentStates())
    // ç»“æœçš„è½¬æ¢å…³ç³»è¡¨
    val result = mutableMapOf<Set<Nondeterministic.State>, Deterministic.State>()
    var nextChar = 'A'
    // æ„å»ºDFAå¼€å§‹çŠ¶æ€
    result[start.equivalentStates()] = Deterministic.State(
                nextChar++.toString(),
                start.equivalentStates().any { it.accept },
                mutableMapOf())
    while (!statesToFind.isEmpty()) {
        // ç°åœ¨å¼€å§‹è€ƒè™‘è¿™ç»„NFAçŠ¶æ€å¯¹åº”çš„DFAçŠ¶æ€
        val theStates = statesToFind.first()
        statesToFind.remove(theStates)
        for (ch in alphabet) {
            val canGoTo = theStates.directConnectedTo(ch)
            val equivalenteStates = canGoTo.equivalentStates
            // ä¸å­˜åœ¨å¯¹åº”DFAçŠ¶æ€ï¼Œæ„å»º
            if (equivalenteStates !in result.keys) {
                result[equivalenteStates] = Deterministic.State(nextChar++.toString(), equivalenteStates.any { it.accept }, mutableMapOf())
                statesToFind.add(equivalenteStates)
            }
            // æ·»åŠ è¯¥çŠ¶æ€åˆ°å…¶ä»–çŠ¶æ€çš„è½¬æ¢å…³ç³»
            result[theStates]!!.transitions[ch] = result[equivalenteStates]!!
        }
    }
    // ä¿å­˜ä¸ºDFAå¹¶è¿”å›
    return Deterministic(result.values.toSet(), result.values.minBy { it.name }!!)
}

ç„¶åå°†è¡¨è¾¾å¼ç¼–è¯‘æˆå¦‚ä¸‹çš„ LUT4:

pub struct LUT4 {
    pub name: String,
    pub initial_value: u16,
    pub input_connections: [usize; 4],
    pub output_connections: usize,
}

ç¼–è¯‘è¿‡ç¨‹å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼Œä»£ç å¤ªä¸‘ä¸å¥½æ„æ€æ‹¿å‡ºæ¥çœ‹æˆ‘å°±æ”¾ä¼ªä»£ç äº†ï¼š

pub fn compile_expression(
    expression: frontend::Expression,
    context: &mut Context,
) -> Result<LUT4, ()> {
    // generate initial_value
    let mut initial_value = 0;
    let mut variables = expression.variables();
    while variables.len() < 4 {
        variables.push(format!("dummy_{}", variables.len()));
    }
    for i, (a, b, c, d) in tagged_cartesian_product(a: (0, 1), b: (0, 1), c: (0, 1), d: (0, 1)).enumerate() {
        let result = expression.evaluate(a, b, c, d);
        initial_value |= result << i;
    }
    // generate input connections
    let mut connections = [0usize; 4];
    for (index, variable) in variables.enumerate() {
        connections[index] = *context.wires.get(*variable).unwrap();
    }
    let id = context.next_id++;
    let name = format!("port{}_LUT4", id);
    context.wires.insert(format!("port{}_LUT4_Z", id), id);
    Ok(LUT4 {
        name,
        initial_value,
        input_connections: connections,
        output_connections: id,
    })
}

æ€»ä¹‹å°±æ˜¯æš´åŠ›æŠŠæ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½å¸¦å…¥ expression æ±‚å‡ºçœŸå€¼è¡¨ï¼Œè¿›è€Œç®—å‡º LUT4 çš„åˆå§‹å€¼ï¼Œå†æ¬¡æé†’è¿™ä¸æ˜¯ç”Ÿäº§ç¯å¢ƒä¸‹çš„åšæ³•ã€‚

ç„¶åå°±æ˜¯ç”Ÿæˆ JSONï¼Œè¿™é‡Œåªå±•ç¤ºä» LUT4 ç”Ÿæˆ Cell çš„ä»£ç ï¼š

pub struct Cell {
    name: String,
    component_type: String,
    parameters: HashMap<String, String>,
    port_directions: HashMap<String, PortDirection>,
    connections: HashMap<String, Vec<usize>>,
}

impl From<LUT4> for Cell {
    fn from(lut: LUT4) -> Self {
        let port_directions = {
            let mut m = HashMap::new();
            m.insert("A".to_string(), PortDirection::Input);
            m.insert("B".to_string(), PortDirection::Input);
            m.insert("C".to_string(), PortDirection::Input);
            m.insert("D".to_string(), PortDirection::Input);
            m.insert("Z".to_string(), PortDirection::Output);
            m
        };
        let parameters = {
            let mut m = HashMap::new();
            m.insert("INIT".to_string(), format!("{:16b}", lut.initial_value));
            m
        };

        let c = ["A", "B", "C", "D"]
            .iter()
            .zip(lut.input_connections.iter())
            .chain(["Z"].iter().zip(iter::once(&lut.output_connections)));
        let mut connections = HashMap::new();
        for (name, &id) in c {
            connections.insert(name.to_string(), vec![id]);
        }

        Self {
            name: lut.name,
            component_type: "LUT4".to_string(),
            parameters,
            port_directions,
            connections,
        }
    }
}

fn horn_satisfiabe(formula: HornFormula) {
  let mut marked = HashSet::new();
  marked.add(âŠ¤);
  while let Some(p) = 
    formula.find(|it| !it.rhs.marked && 
      it.lhs.all(|it| marked.contains(it))
    ).map(|it| it.rhs) {
    marked.add(p);
  }
  return !marked.contains(âŠ¥);
}

entry.title: Parsing â€¢ ç§»è¿›-å½’çº¦åˆ†æ
entry.content:
å›å¿†ä½ å¾ˆå¯èƒ½åœ¨å¤§ä¸€å¤§äºŒ1å†™è¿‡çš„è¿ç”¨æ ˆè¿›è¡Œè¡¨è¾¾å¼æ±‚å€¼çš„ç¨‹åºï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†å…¶ç®€åŒ–åˆ°åªæ”¯æŒåŠ æ³•å’Œä¹˜æ³•ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œç»™å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªRustè¯­è¨€çš„ä¾‹å­ï¼ˆå†™çš„æ¯”è¾ƒéšæ„â€¦â€¦ï¼‰ï¼Œå¤ªé•¿ä¸çœ‹å…šå¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥è·³è¿‡çœ‹ä¸‹é¢çš„åˆ†æï¼š

    let mut input = String::new();
    stdin().read_to_string(&mut input).unwrap();
    input = input.trim().to_owned();
    let mut current_number = String::new();
    let mut stack = Vec::new();
    for ch in input.chars() {
        match ch {
            '0'..='9' => current_number.push(ch),
            '+' | '*' => {
                if !current_number.is_empty() {
                    stack.push(Token::Value(i32::from_str(&current_number).unwrap()));
                    current_number = String::new();
                }
                let top_op = stack.iter().rev()
                    .find_map(|&it| if let Token::Op(op) = it { Some(op) } else { None });
                if top_op.is_some() {
                    let mut top_op = top_op.unwrap();
                    // ä¸‹é¢çš„æ¡ä»¶å®é™…ä¸Šæ˜¯"æ ˆä¸Šæœ€åä¸€ä¸ªæ“ä½œç¬¦ä¼˜å…ˆçº§å¤§äºç­‰äºå½“å‰è¯»åˆ°çš„æ“ä½œç¬¦"
                    while ch == '+' || top_op == '*' {
                        let op2 = stack.pop().unwrap();
                        let op = stack.pop().unwrap(); // should be equal to top_op
                        let op1 = stack.pop().unwrap();
                        stack.push(Token::Value(eval(op1, op, op2)));
                        let next_top_op = stack.iter().rev()
                            .find_map(|&it| if let Token::Op(op) = it { Some(op) } else { None });
                        if next_top_op.is_none() { break; }
                        top_op = next_top_op.unwrap()
                    }
                }
                stack.push(Token::Op(ch));
            }
            _ => unreachable!()
        }
    }
    if !current_number.is_empty() {
        stack.push(Token::Value(i32::from_str(&current_number).unwrap()));
        current_number.clear();
    }
    let mut top_op = stack.iter().rev()
        .find_map(|&it| if let Token::Op(op) = it { Some(op) } else { None });
    while top_op.is_some() {
        let op2 = stack.pop().unwrap();
        let op = stack.pop().unwrap();
        let op1 = stack.pop().unwrap();
        stack.push(Token::Value(eval(op1, op, op2)));
        top_op = stack.iter().rev()
            .find_map(|&it| if let Token::Op(op) = it { Some(op) } else { None });
    }
		println!("{:?}", stack[0]);

æˆ‘ä»¬ä»¥è¡¨è¾¾å¼$1+2*3+4$çš„æ±‚å€¼æ¥è§‚å¯Ÿè¿™ä¸€è¿‡ç¨‹ï¼š

  1. è¾“å…¥æ•°å­—1ï¼Œå‹å…¥æ ˆä¸­

  2. è¾“å…¥æ“ä½œç¬¦'+'ï¼Œå‹å…¥æ ˆä¸­

  3. è¾“å…¥æ•°å­—2ï¼Œå‹å…¥æ ˆä¸­

  4. è¾“å…¥æ“ä½œç¬¦'*'ï¼Œå‹å…¥æ ˆä¸­

  5. è¾“å…¥æ•°å­—3ï¼Œå‹å…¥æ ˆä¸­

  6. è¾“å…¥æ“ä½œç¬¦'+'ï¼Œä¼˜å…ˆçº§ä½äºæ ˆä¸­æœ€åä¸€ä¸ªå‹å…¥çš„è¿ç®—ç¬¦ï¼Œå…ˆå¯¹æ ˆä¸­å†…å®¹æ±‚å€¼ï¼Œå†å°†'+'å‹å…¥æ ˆä¸­

    • '+'ä¼˜å…ˆçº§ç­‰äº'+'ï¼Œæ±‚å€¼

  7. çœ‹åˆ°æ•°å­—4ï¼Œå‹å…¥

  8. æ²¡æœ‰è¾“å…¥äº†ï¼Œä¸æ–­æ±‚å€¼ç›´åˆ°æ²¡æœ‰æ›´å¤šè¿ç®—ç¬¦

è¿™é‡Œçš„11å°±æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬æ±‚å¾—å¾—ç­”æ¡ˆã€‚

ç§»è¿›å’Œå½’çº¦

æˆ‘ä»¬çœ‹åˆ°ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸Šé¢çš„åˆ†æè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­å‡ºç°äº†ä¸¤ç§æ“ä½œï¼š

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å°†â€œå€¼â€ã€â€œæ“ä½œç¬¦â€æ¨å¹¿åˆ°â€œæ–‡æ³•å…ƒç´ â€ï¼Œå¾—åˆ°äº†æ–‡æ³•åˆ†æä¸­çš„ç§»è¿›å’Œå½’çº¦

é‚£ä¹ˆæˆ‘ä»¬å°±èƒ½å°†ä¸Šé¢çš„ä¾‹å­æ¨å¹¿åˆ°æ›´ä¸€èˆ¬çš„ï¼Œéæ•°å­—çš„åœºæ™¯ï¼Œä»¥æ–‡æ³•2ï¼š $$ Expr \rightarrow id | Expr + Expr | Expr * Expr $$ å’Œè¡¨è¾¾å¼$a+b*c+d$ä¸ºä¾‹ï¼ˆå›¾ä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰è“è‰²èŠ‚ç‚¹å‡ä»£è¡¨$Expr$ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­å¤æ‚$Expr$å·²ç»ç”»ä¸ºASTçš„æ ·å­ï¼‰ï¼š

å†²çª

åœ¨ç§»è¿›-å½’çº¦åˆ†æè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œå¯èƒ½ä¼šé‡åˆ°æŸäº›æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œæœ‰å¤šç§å¯èƒ½ä½¿ç”¨çš„è¡Œä¸ºï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ï¼š

æ­¤æ—¶æ˜¯å¦åº”å½“å°†1+2å½’çº¦ä¸º3ï¼Ÿè¿™å°±è¦ç­‰åˆ°ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªæ“ä½œç¬¦åˆ°æ¥æ‰èƒ½å†³å®šã€‚

ç§»è¿›-å½’çº¦å†²çª

å½“æŸä¸ªè¾“å…¥å¯ä»¥é€‰æ‹©ä¸æ ˆä¸­å†…å®¹ç»“åˆï¼Œè¿›è¡Œå½’çº¦ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥é€‰æ‹©ç›´æ¥å‹å…¥æ ˆï¼Œåç»­å†è¿›è¡Œå½’çº¦æ—¶ï¼Œå°±è¯´æˆ‘ä»¬é‡åˆ°äº†ä¸€ä¸ªç§»è¿›-å½’çº¦å†²çªã€‚

ä¸Šè¿°çš„ä¾‹å­å°±æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå…¸å‹çš„ç§»è¿›-å½’çº¦å†²çªã€‚

å½“æˆ‘ä»¬é‡åˆ°äº†æŸä¸ªè¾“å…¥ä¸æ ˆä¸­å†…å®¹ç»“åˆï¼Œå…¶ç»“æ„ç¬¦åˆå¤šä¸ªäº§ç”Ÿå¼æ—¶ï¼Œå¯ä»¥æœ‰å¤šç§æ–¹å¼è¿›è¡Œå½’çº¦ï¼Œè¿™æ—¶å°±è¯´æˆ‘ä»¬é‡åˆ°äº†ä¸€ä¸ªå½’çº¦-å½’çº¦å†²çªã€‚

Define $FIRST(Î±)$, where $Î±$ is any string of grammar symbols, to be the set of terminals that begin strings derived from $Î±$. If $\alpha \stackrel{*}{\Rightarrow} \epsilon$, then $\epsilon$ is also in $FIRST(Î±)$. â€”â€” â€œCompilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools, 2/eâ€

å®šä¹‰$FIRST(Î±)$ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­$\alpha$æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªè¯­æ³•ç¬¦å·æ„æˆçš„ä»»æ„ä¸²ï¼Œä¸ºä¸€ç»„å¯ä»¥è¢«$\alpha$æ¨å¯¼å‡ºçš„ç»ˆç»“ç¬¦ä¸²çš„èµ·å§‹å­—ç¬¦çš„é›†åˆã€‚å¦‚æœ$\alpha \stackrel{*}{\Rightarrow} \epsilon$ï¼Œé‚£$\epsilon$ä¹Ÿåœ¨$FIRST(Î±)$ä¸­ã€‚

åŒç†ï¼Œæ•°å­¦ç¬¦å·â€¦â€¦

  1. If X is a terminal, then $FIRST(X) = {X}$.

  2. If X is a nonterminal and $X â†’ Y_1Y_2 ... Y_k$ is a production for some $k \ge 1$, then place 'a' in $FIRST(X)$ if for some $i$, 'a' is in $FIRST(Y_i)$, and $\epsilon$ is in all of $FIRST(Y_1), ..., FIRST(Y_{i â€“ 1})$; that is, $Y_1Y_2...Y_{i-1} \stackrel{*}{\Rightarrow} \epsilon$.

    If $\epsilon$ is in $FIRST(Y_j)$ for all $j = 1, 2, ..., k$, then add $\epsilon$ to $FIRST(X)$.

  3. If $X \rightarrow \epsilon$ is a production, then add $\epsilon$ to $FIRST(X)$.

fn alt<R>(parsers: Vec<Fn(string) -> (R, string) | Error>, input: string) -> (R, string) | Error {
	for parser in parsers {
		if parser(input) != Error {
			return parser(input)
		}
	}
	return Error
}

// æ¥å—ä¸€ä¸ªparserå‡½æ•°ï¼Œè¿”å›å…¶é‡å¤åŒ¹é…0æ¬¡ä»¥ä¸Šçš„ç»“æœï¼Œç›¸å½“äº*
fn many0(parser: Fn(string) -> (R, string) | Error, input: string) -> (Vec<R>, string) | Error {
	result = new Vec();
	while parser(input) != error {
		r, input = parser(input)
		result.push(r)
	}
	return (result, input)
}

fn tag(tagname: string, code: string) -> (string, string) | Error {
	if code.starts_with(tagname) {
		return tagname, code[len(tagname):]
	} else {
		return Error
	}
}

	rhs, rest = expression(rest)?
	return Expression {lhs, "*", rhs}
}

	// ä¸ç†è§£çš„è¯è€ƒè™‘ä¸€ä¸‹1+2*3ä¼šæ€ä¹ˆè¢«parseå°±çŸ¥é“äº†
	return alt([
		add,
		mul,
		ident,
		constant,
		in_brackets,
	], code)
}
fn in_brackets(code: string) -> (InBrackets, string) | Error {
	bracket, rest = tag("(",code)?
	expr, rest = expression(rest)?
	bracket, rest = tag(")",code)?
	return InBrackets(expr), rest
}
fn ident(code: string) -> (Ident, string) | Error {
	return alt(tag("a", code), tag("b", code),........) 
}
fn digit(code: string) -> (string, string) | Error {
	return alt(tag("0", code), tag("1", code),........) 
}
fn constant(code: string) -> (Constant, string) | Error {
	return many0(digit, code)
}

      fn to_ast(first: RValue, rest: Vec<(String, RValue)>) -> BinOp {
  let mut current_lhs = first;
  for (op, value) in rest.into_iter() {
      current_lhs = BinOp {
          operator: op,
          lhs: Box::new(current_lhs),
          rhs: Box::new(value),
      }
      .into()
  }
  current_lhs.try_into().unwrap()
}

entry.title: Hello zola!
entry.content:
I wrote a lot of blogs, and I used to use hexo as a static site generator, it kind of work well, but I'm afraid with more and more posts I have, the speed of hexo become unacceptable, moreover, the plugin system works well if I add only one plugin, but become odd if there're many plugins work together:

Here's an image from my origin blog, powered by hexo:

Ouch!

And then, since I'm a big fan of Rust, I found zola, though this tool is not as complete as hexo, I can use its shortcodes feature to embed different of things to my blog!

For example, terminal record:

Which I never imagined when using hexo!

And zola do make it easier to customize a theme, in hexo, if I want to customize a theme, I have to fork it, and do some edit on it. But in zola I can do this easily by override a template block.

But there remains some problems:

  • The translations in a theme cannot be used in the site based on that theme. Hope will fixed after #1148.
  • Cannot paginate over another section.1

Anyway, I'll absolutly move my blog to zola.

Also I'm looking forward to contribute something to this project, and I started with migrating a theme, which I'll also used on my blog.

Hope zola will become a better project in the future!

1

Or maybe I misunderstood the pagination feature ...

é¦–å…ˆæœ¬æ–‡ä¸­æ‰€è¿°çš„ç¼–è¯‘å™¨ç¼–è¯‘ä¸€ä¸ªç¨‹åºçš„è¿‡ç¨‹å¦‚ä¸‹2ï¼š

æ˜¾ç„¶å¾ˆå¤šä»£ç éƒ½ä¸ç”¨æˆ‘ä»¬è‡ªå·±å†™ï¼Œç”Ÿåœ¨è¿™æ ·ä¸€ä¸ªæœ‰ä¸°å¯Œå·¥å…·çš„æ—¶ä»£æ—¢æ˜¯å¹¸è¿ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¸€ç§ä¸å¹¸ã€‚

è¯æ³•åˆ†æ

åœ¨æ­¤ç»™å‡º flex çš„å…³é”®éƒ¨åˆ†ä»£ç ï¼š

"char"                      {yylval.type=Char; return TYPE;}
"int"                       {yylval.type=Int; return TYPE;}
"double"                    {yylval.type=Double; return TYPE;}
"string"                    {yylval.type=String; return TYPE;}
"if"                        {return IF;}
"else"                      {return ELSE;}
"while"                     {return WHILE;}
"print"                     {return PRINT;}
([-])?[0-9]+                {yylval.int_value=atoi(yytext); return INT_LITERAL;}
([-])?[0-9]+\.[0-9]*        {yylval.double_value=atof(yytext); return DOUBLE_LITERAL;}
[a-zA-Z][0-9a-zA-Z_]*       {yylval.string_value=strdup(yytext); return IDENTIFY;}
"=="                        {return EQUAL;}
"!="                        {return NONEQUAL;}
"<"                         {return *yytext;}
"<="                        {return LESSEQ;}
">"                         {return *yytext;}
">="                        {return GREATEREQ;}
"+"                         {return *yytext;}
"-"                         {return *yytext;}
"*"                         {return *yytext;}
"/"                         {return *yytext;}
"["                         {return *yytext;}
"]"                         {return *yytext;}
[ \t]                       {}
.                           {return *yytext;}

è¯­æ³•åˆ†æ

åœ¨æ­¤ç»™å‡º bison çš„å…³é”®éƒ¨åˆ†ä»£ç ï¼š

program:
    program statement           
    |                          
    ;

assign:
    '=' expression             
    ;

defineStatement:
    TYPE IDENTIFY ';'
    | TYPE IDENTIFY '[' INT_LITERAL ']' ';' 
    | TYPE IDENTIFY assign ';'
    ;

assignStatement:
    referenceExpression assign ';'
    ;

statementList:
    statementList statement                 
    |                                       
    ;

block:
    '{' statementList '}' 
    ;

ifStatement:
    IF expression block                   
    | IF expression block ELSE block        
    ;

whileStatement:
    WHILE expression block                  
;

printStatement:
    PRINT '(' expression ')' ';'
;

statement:
    defineStatement
    | assignStatement
    | block
    | ifStatement
    | whileStatement
    | printStatement
;

referenceExpression:
    IDENTIFY 
    | IDENTIFY '[' expression ']' 

atomExpression:
    INT_LITERAL                            
    | DOUBLE_LITERAL                      
    | referenceExpression                  
    | '(' expression ')'                  
    ;

unaryOperator:
    '+'
    | '-'
    | '!'
    ;

unaryExpression:
    atomExpression                        
    | unaryOperator atomExpression         
;

binaryOrAtomExpression:
    unaryExpression                                    
    | binaryOrAtomExpression '+' unaryExpression       
    | binaryOrAtomExpression '-' unaryExpression   
    | binaryOrAtomExpression '*' unaryExpression        
    | binaryOrAtomExpression '/' unaryExpression      
    | binaryOrAtomExpression '<' unaryExpression       
    | binaryOrAtomExpression '>' unaryExpression       
    | binaryOrAtomExpression LESSEQ     unaryExpression 
    | binaryOrAtomExpression GREATEREQ  unaryExpression
    | binaryOrAtomExpression EQUAL      unaryExpression 
    | binaryOrAtomExpression NONEQUAL   unaryExpression 
;

    ;

æ³¨æ„æ­¤å¤„æ²¡æœ‰ç»™å‡ºç›¸åº”çš„è¡Œä¸ºä»£ç ï¼Œå› ä¸ºé¦–å…ˆéœ€è¦ç†è§£ASTæ‰èƒ½æ˜ç™½è¿™äº›è¡Œä¸ºã€‚

ASTï¼ˆæŠ½è±¡è¯­æ³•æ ‘ï¼‰

æŠ½è±¡è¯­æ³•æ ‘å°†è¯­æ³•åˆ†æå¾—åˆ°çš„è¯­æ³•å•å…ƒç»„ç»‡æˆæ ‘çŠ¶ã€‚

åŸºæœ¬ä¸Šæ¯ä¸ªstatementå’Œexpressionéƒ½å¯ä»¥å¯¹åº”ASTä¸Šçš„ä¸€ä¸ªnodeã€‚

æœ¬ç¼–è¯‘å™¨çš„ASTè®¾è®¡

éƒ¨åˆ†å‚è€ƒäº†llvmçš„ASTè®¾è®¡ã€‚

å› æ­¤æˆ‘ä»¬å°±èƒ½å†™å‡º %union å’Œ %typeï¼š

%union {

%token <type> TYPE

%left '>' '<' LESSEQ GREATEREQ EQUAL NONEQUAL
%left '+' '-'
%left '*' '/'

%type <node> statement assignStatement statementList block ifStatement whileStatement defineStatement printStatement
%type <node> expression referenceExpression assign atomExpression unaryExpression binaryOrAtomExpression
%type <node> program

æ•´ä¸ªç¨‹åºæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ª CompoundStatementï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è¦æŠŠç»“æœå­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªå…¨å±€å˜é‡ä¸­ï¼š

binaryOrAtomExpression:

    | binaryOrAtomExpression '+' unaryExpression        {$$=(ASTNode*)create_binary_operation_result('+',(RValue*)$1,(RValue*)$3);}

    | binaryOrAtomExpression LESSEQ     unaryExpression {$$=(ASTNode*)create_binary_operation_result(LESSEQ, (RValue*)$1,(RValue*)$3);}

å…¶ä¸­ get_symbol ä»æ ˆé¡¶å‘æ ˆåº•å¯»æ‰¾åå­—ä¸º name çš„ç¬¦å·ã€‚

åœ¨ add_symbol æ—¶ï¼Œä¼šè®¾ç½® symbol çš„ namespace_id ä¸º frame çš„ namespace_idï¼Œè¿™åœ¨ä»£ç ç”Ÿæˆæ—¶ä¼šä½œä¸ºå˜é‡åç§°çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†å‡ºç°ã€‚

æ¯é‡åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ª blockï¼Œå°± push ä¸€ä¸ª frameï¼Œç¦»å¼€ block æ—¶ pop å³å¯ï¼Œè¿™æ ·è¿™ä¸ª block å†…å£°æ˜çš„ symbol å°±ä¼šè·å¾—ä¸€ä¸ªå’Œè¿™ä¸ª block å¯¹åº”çš„ namespace_idã€‚

static void generate_code(DeclareStatement *node) {

static void generate_code(AssignStatement *node) {
    ((LValue *) (node->lhs))->generate_lvalue_code((LValue *) (node->lhs));
    node->rhs->generate_rvalue_code(node->rhs);
    char *rvalue_ir = node->rhs->rvalue_ir(node->rhs);
    char *lvalue_ir = node->lhs->lvalue_ir(node->lhs);
    printf("store %s %s, %s* %s\n",
           type_string(((RValue *) (node->lhs))->type),
           rvalue_ir,
           type_string(((RValue *) (node->lhs))->type),
           lvalue_ir);
    free(rvalue_ir);
    free(lvalue_ir);
}

static void generate_rvalue_code(VariableReference *rValue) {
char *rvalue_ir_string = ((RValue *) rValue)->rvalue_ir((RValue*) rValue);

    printf("%s = load %s, %s* %s\n",
           rvalue_ir_string,
           type_name(rValue->variable),
           type_name(rValue->variable),
           lvalue_ir_string);
    free(rvalue_ir_string);
    free(lvalue_ir_string);
}

// å·¦å€¼æ— éœ€è¯»å–å‡ºæ¥

}

static char *lvalue_ir(VariableReference *lValue) {
    char *result = malloc(128);

    return result;
}

// åšå³å€¼æ—¶irä¸­çš„å˜é‡å
static char *rvalue_ir(VariableReference *rValue) {

    sprintf(result, "%%temp_%zu", rValue->temp_register_id);
    return result;
}

æ—¢ç„¶æ˜¯factoryï¼Œå¹²è„†æŠŠä»å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ„é€ RegexComponentçš„æ–¹æ³•ä¹Ÿå¡è¿›å»ï¼š

/**
 * è¡¥ä¸Šçœç•¥çš„'.'å·
 */
private fun addOmittedDotOperator(str: String): String {
    val theString = StringBuilder()
    for ((index, ch) in str.withIndex()) {
        theString.append(ch)
        if (index != str.length - 1) {
            if ((ch.isLowerCase() || ch.isDigit() || ch == ')') &&
                    (str[index + 1].isLowerCase() || str[index + 1].isDigit() || str[index + 1] == '(') ||
                    (ch == '*' && !isRegexOperator(str[index + 1]) && str[index + 1] != ')')) {
                theString.append('.')
            }
        }
    }
    return theString.toString()
}

/**
* å®é™…æ„é€ è¿‡ç¨‹
*/
private fun fromFormalString(string: String): RegexComponent {
    if (string == "")
        return nullCharacter
    try {
        return when {
            string.startsWith('(') && pairedRightBracketIndex(string) == string.length - 1 ->
                fromFormalString(eraseUselessBracketPairs(string))
            string.length == 1 ->
                TerminalCharacter(string)
            string.firstLayerContain('|') ->
                string.splitFirstLayerBy('|').map { fromFormalString(it) }.reduce { acc, regexPart -> acc or regexPart }
            string.firstLayerContain('.') ->
                string.splitFirstLayerBy('.').map { fromFormalString(it) }.reduce { acc, regexPart -> acc concat regexPart }
            string.endsWith('*') ->
                if (string.startsWith('(')) {
                    fromFormalString(string.slice(1 until string.length - 2)).repeat()
                } else {
                    fromFormalString(string.slice(0 until string.length - 1)).repeat()
                }
            else ->
                throw IllegalArgumentException("Can not construct from string $string")
        }
    } catch (_: StringIndexOutOfBoundsException) {
        throw IllegalArgumentException("Can not construct from string $string")
    } catch (_: IllegalArgumentException) {
        throw IllegalArgumentException("Can not construct from string $string")
    }
}

/**
 * ä»å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ä¸­æ„é€  RegexComponent
 */
fun fromString(string: String): RegexComponent {
    return fromFormalString(addOmittedDotOperator(string))
}
